prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Field setup: we will observe a mosaic to cover the brightest part of the dust lane (similar to the Science Verification observed area), and centered at the AGN position of Centaurus A, and oriented along the position angle P.A. = 120$^{\rm o}$. Separation between pointings is nyquiest. Given an estimated largest angular scale of 20 arcsec in both isotopologues of CO, ACA will not be needed.
Calibration: Standard calibration but we recommend to observe the center of the galaxy every cycle, as we can self-calibrate using the bright unresolved continuum component.
Sensitivities: The ratio 12 CO(1-0)/13 CO(1-0) found by Eckart et al. 1990 in single dish observations is 6 - 13 from outside to the center. We set the sensitivity a factor of 2 deeper to account for this so 13CO will be easily detected as well. The 12CO/C18O ratio is > 55, but it will be detected in the most massive regions.

Field setup: we will observe a mosaic to cover the brightest part of the dust lane (similar to the Science Verification observed area), and centered at the AGN position of Centaurus A, and oriented along the position angle P.A. = 120$^{\rm o}$. Separation between pointings is nyquiest.
Given the estimated largest angular scale of 20 arcsec we require ACA and Total Power Array observations to recover missing flux.
Calibration: Standard calibration but we recommend to observe the center of the galaxy every cycle, as we can self-calibrate using the bright unresolved continuum component.
Sensitivities: The ratio 12 CO(1-0)/13 CO(1-0) found by Eckart et al. 1990 in single dish observations is 6 - 13 from outside to the center. We assume the same ratio for J=2-1. We set the sensitivity a factor of 2 deeper to account for this so 13CO will be easily detected as well. The 12CO/C18O ratio is > 55, but it will be detected in the most massive regions.

Field setup: we will observe a mosaic to cover the dust lane in the inner 5 x 1.4, and centered at the AGN position of Centaurus A, and oriented along the position angle P.A. = 120$^{\rm o}$. Separation between pointings is nyquiest.
Given the estimated largest angular scale of 40 arcsec from our previous SMA observations (see science justification) we require ACA and Total Power Array observations to recover missing flux.
Calibration: Standard calibration but we recommend to observe the center of the galaxy every cycle, as we can self-calibrate using the bright unresolved continuum component.
Sensitivities For 1 km/s and 5 sigma, we will reach sensitivities of ~10^5 Msun (GMC low end) within a beam of 18 pc. Assume a ’standard’ conversion factor of XCO = 2.0 × 10^20cm−2(K kms−1)−1.

Field setup: we will observe a mosaic to cover the dust lane in the inner 4 x 1.4, and centered at the AGN position of Centaurus A, and oriented along the position angle P.A. = 120$^{\rm o}$. Separation between pointings is nyquiest.
Given the estimated largest angular scale of 40 arcsec from our previous SMA observations (see science justification) we require ACA and Total Power Array observations to recover missing flux.
Calibration: Standard calibration but we recommend to observe the center of the galaxy every cycle, as we can self-calibrate using the bright unresolved continuum component.
Sensitivities: For 1 km/s and 5 sigma, we will reach sensitivities of ~10^5 Msun (GMC low end) within a beam of 18 pc. Assume a ’standard’ conversion factor of XCO = 2.0 × 10^20cm−2(K kms−1)−1. Eckart et al. 1990 found using single dish that 12CO(2-1)/12CO(1-0) intensity ratio is almost 1.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Many large elliptical galaxies contain embedded disks of dust and gas, remnants of a merger with a smaller gas-rich galaxy. The physical properties of such disks, and the resulting initial conditions for star formation are very different from those in disk galaxies and starburst galaxies. We will study these in detail by modelling the molecular gas in the embedded dusty gas disk ('dark band') of the only nearby giant elliptical, NGC 5128 (host of the radio source Centaurus A). We will apply PDR and radiative transfer models to the optically think 12CO and the optically thin 13CO and C18O J=1-0 and 2-1 transitions in maps of 18 pc resolution over the inner several kpc of the galaxy. From the maps we will deduce the mass and temperature, for individual clumps and as a function of radius, of the gas in the extended disk, and investigate the relation of the dense molecular gas conditions to the enhanced star formation in the disk.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
